q: Iraq. The differences were not personal, Donald Rumsfeld says. He recalls receiving a book that Henry Kissinger had written, with the inscription, "To an occasional adversary and a permanent friend." When I started working on the book, Henry Kissinger said, "You tell it like it was.' We differed on some issues, and there"s nothing wrong with that. It was professional and healthy, Donald Rumsfeld says. Working on the book meant second-guessing his memory. In 1983, Donald Rumsfeld was a special Middle East envoy for President Lyndon Johnson Ronald Reagan and met with Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein ,

I can today confirm that I've resigned as Downing Street director of communications, Andy Coulson said in a statement.
